title: Do people even know what toxic means anymore?

replies.body:
Agreed. You see it on the PB&M board too often too, people will call someone "toxic" when the chat is really just negative or pessimistic. While some language certainly is deserving the toxic label, too frequently I feel people use "toxic" because there's nothing catchy to describe language that's less than that.

As for in-game, the only time I see people call others "toxic" for no reason is when they're already tilted off the face of the Earth.

i think games will be better if they removed chat and put voice chat..unlike normal chat i cant curse or say something bad to players iam talking directly to,like overwatch system...ive played overwatch for quite sometime now and played rankeds..and i can hardly find any toxicity there..we r just laughing at bad plays when we lose

I'm hesitant on voice chat. There are some game communities that handle voice chat admirably (Mech Warrior Online comes to mind), and others that leave you scrambling to find the mute button. My concern is if League does require you to mute voice you'll be worse off than you are right now. I've seen players learn to play this game when they're primarily on voice chat with their friends, and it results in players who ping less. Inevitably people will ping less frequently a year after voice chat is introduced than they do before it is. Currently muting chat doesn't effect you too bad because most important content is via pings, but if you lose voice *and* pings then you're in a pickle.

While there likely will be some players who remember there are people on the other side of the monitor and behave better, there are also players who have gotten use to raging at their monitors instead of typing out their frustrations. I don't think there'll be a significant improvement in behavior with a voice system, but it would be significantly harder to regulate.

"Maybe if you weren't trash going 2-17 initial feeding, maybe we would have won"

This is unhelpful, inflammatory, and pointless to say in chat. it is just as easy to say, "we had trouble winning because the enemy got fed." This doesn't require you to single anybody out.

Singling players out is never a good idea because it will just inflame the situation more and cause more arguing. That is why Riot considers it toxic.

Actually, it does. Let me explain why. 

It's not toxic to point out someone was literally just feeding the entire game, not due to being bad, but because they were just a bad person  and wanted to ruin the game. Toxic would be this person dying a few times and me just going ham on them for no reason. Pointing out a flaw in someone, and declaring what they are doing to a team isn't toxic, that's called 'Stating the facts' any child knows this my friend. 

Riot's version of toxic is saying anything negative at all, which, in itself, riot is toxic for actually not understanding what a word means.

I'm beginning to think you aren't familiar with tilt. When a person tilts they become much more defensive than normal. Saying things that are factually true while singling them out is essentially toxic because of the response it is guaranteed to elicit.

This is unnecessary and inflammatory when there are significantly simpler ways to express your opinion without singling the player out. And if they are really annoying enough that you want to single them out and point out that things are their fault, you would be better off muting them anyways.

There is no reason to single them out, and there is no reason to defend the act of doing so.

Tilt is a concept that derives from League, I don't understand it because in the real world we use English. 

Now, what you're doing is molly coddling, molly coddling is when you baby someone, who did something wrong or not correct to a degree and go "Better luck next time, it's okay you'll do fine" rather than berating them and giving them the facts as to how they messed up, this is why the community is so messed up right now, you're all children, worse than that, you're hugbox children. 

There is a million reasons to single a person out, it humbles them, it makes them look bad, it puts them in the spot light to either bow out or toughen up and get better. We do this to create men, it's called survival of the fittest.

> [{quoted}](name=Jayceonmyface,realm=NA,application-id=ZGEFLEUQ,discussion-id=b8fYIH9M,comment-id=0018000000000000,timestamp=2017-09-27T09:26:13.794+0000)
>
> Tilt is a concept that derives from League, I don't understand it because in the real world we use English. 

Tilt may be a restricted term, but the actual effect is called Emotional Flooding. This is when a person becomes emotionally unstable and makes worse and worse decisions, creating a downward spiral of becoming more stressed and making worse mistakes.

It isn't exclusive to league of legends, athletes in major sports can suffer from it all the time, people who game the stock market can become similarly afflicted, and posters and commenters on social media can argue themselves into a corner and humiliate themselves not of their own free will, but out of an emotional overreaction that overrides rational thought.

It is a fact of human nature, and it is something that ought to be taken into consideration when interacting with people who may be suffering its effects. Since it can affect the outcome of your interactions with them.

> Now, what you're doing is molly coddling, molly coddling is when you baby someone, who did something wrong or not correct to a degree and go "Better luck next time, it's okay you'll do fine" rather than berating them and giving them the facts as to how they messed up, this is why the community is so messed up right now, you're all children, worse than that, you're hugbox children.

> There is a million reasons to single a person out, it humbles them, it makes them look bad, it puts them in the spot light to either bow out or toughen up and get better. We do this to create men, it's called survival of the fittest.

OK, so basically people are either 'weak' or 'strong' and they ought to be poked and prodded when it is appropriate in order to make them shape up or drop out? You are entitled to have that opinion, but tell me something; How is that working out for you? Do people shape up? or do they overreact and ruin your game further?

I'm arguing based on results, not just based on how people should or shouldn't be treated. In my own experience, players tilt less and are much less likely to ruin my game if I am friendly and polite to them from the get-go. A little respect and understanding shown can go a long way.

When someone's tilted enough to start inting, I'm probably going to call them out on it. They already know what they're doing. It's not like they think they're not inting if they're inting.

Totally right about tilt, but at that point it doesn't really matter.

The problem with assuming that they are inting is twofold. If they are not inting, and just severely tilted, they are just going to react worse out of anger at being misunderstood and unfairly accused of something, and if they are inting you are just giving them attention for it and giving them a reason to do it more (because lashing out appears to be working to get others to pay attention to their frustration).

It is much more effective to shift over to their side, appear as an ally, then bring them back to rational cooperation with the rest of the team by making them feel like a part of the whole.

Yup I get what you're saying. I call em out on it and ignore em after that. I don't respect assumptions so I don't make em, I only say someone's inting when they actually are. Inting is intentional feeding, no amount of teamwork is likely to overcome such a deficit. Frankly, I think it's worthless to try and work with someone who's inting. 

I call it out, mute, play, report, move on.

First off you could receive a report every single game you play, but if you're not actually flaming, selling your items for troll shit and running it down mid, NOTHING will happen to your account

What people _usually_ get reported for is the bs that accompanies "Can I get help mid?". Not saying this was you but what happens next is a mixture of "ff", "but you didn't come when I asked", "yeah but X player won't group" "useless" "how can you say that when you never gank lol bad jg" etc

That's it. If you're being passive-aggressive, griefing, begging for surrenders, or just talking about how bad the plays are you're overall being negative and not using the chat for its true purpose. The misuses are clearly outlined in the TOS and Summoner Code.

This is by no means a personal attack on you. I only go around making similar posts to enlighten the community as to what the true intent of chat is and why "Mediocre" insults are getting hammered.

Its pretty simpled. You're not going to win every game, and even in the ones you win, you're probably not going to win early every game. In fact, some games you're going to get stomped and it will def be an uphill battle. This is frustrating.]

You will be punished just like the person running it down mid telling you all "%%%"

It just does not happen unless you're in a party with the synergy of a God, I'm sorry, but you're wrong.

He's a weak link, top lane is going 0-5 by 10 minutes? He's a weak link, and you can blame the jungler just a bit for not ganking or fail ganking. 

It's a team game, if the team isn't doing well, best to just throw in the towel, bow out, and try again, not slog out a 40+ minute match pretending you're Tyler1 and carrying as yet another smurf Draven account, doesn't work like that. No, you slap his wrist, and tell him not to do that again. If your friend gets into a fight and gets his ass kicked, do you just go "Lmao nice" no, you give his head a shake and explain to him it's not a good idea to fight people two times your age and size. 

The Point i'm making in all this, League likes to mollycoddle the stupid. The players who don't want to win, who just want to go "lmao it's just blind shut up" or "Lol who cares just a game dude" they mollycoddle these scum, these people who legit join games just to troll, and yes, this is trolling by the way. You as a person, are obligated to call out people's fuck ups and try and help them better themselves. That is your god given right as a human being to help your fellow man, and if helping your fellow man means he needs to have his pants pulled down infront of millions just to have him laughed at, you had better do just that.
